awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a high speed cell sorter for interdisciplinary student research and training in Biological Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Illinois State University to purchase a high-speed fluorescence activated cell sorter (FACS).  These powerful instruments are widely used in many fields of basic research for identification and rapid isolation of living cells on the basis of size/shape and the color of their fluorescence after incubation with specific dyes.  Four major faculty users and seven minor faculty users in three different departments on campus will benefit from the use of this state-of-the-art instrument in their research, which permits experiments that are not currently possible. The FACS will be widely used by undergraduate and graduate students directly as part of their research training.  Additionally, students in several courses on campus will receive hands-on training on sample preparation, data collection and analysis, which provides them with important laboratory skills. Underrepresented minority students in other campus programs will be actively recruited to participate in these research activities. These unique opportunities support the institution's goal for students to engage in high-quality, high-impact educational experiences.

The FACS accommodates particles of many sizes ranging from bacteria to very large cells. Multiple lasers allow for simultaneous detection of numerous different parameters and mixtures of cells can be rapidly isolated to greater than 99% purity.  This instrument will enable interdisciplinary research on white blood cells and immune function in reptiles, aging and the immune system in mice, disease ecology in bumblebees, host-parasite interactions in insects, separation and study of avian blood cells, analysis of Leishmania parasites, study of neuron function in the insect brain, and studies on pollen production in plants. Acquisition of this instrument will also help recruit and retain talented faculty, including women.  The results of these diverse studies can have wide-ranging impact from disease ecology to conservation efforts to understanding basic cell functions and will have a significant impact on research productivity at Illinois State University.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award allowed us to purchase a state-of-the art research instrument (flow cytometer) and has advanced interdisciplinary efforts in research and training at Illinois State University. Flow cytometry technology has enabled critical research in many cell biology-related fields through its ability to identify and isolate rare cell populations. This technology is particularly powerful in non-model systems as many of the uses do not require species-specific reagents (i.e., cell proliferation, separation by cell size, etc.) and a large range of particle sizes (bacteria to parasites) can be analyzed.  We used grant funds to purchase a multi-laser flow cytometer with high-speed cell sorting capability (BD FACSMelody). The instrument is open for use by any faculty (any department) or students (undergraduate and graduate) at Illinois State University and will continue to be available in the future past the end of the grant award. The FACS Melody has been used by ISU scientists in areas including reptile and insect physiology, immunity, fungal genetics, and cell biology and it allowed us to establish some exciting new research collaborations. Given the complex nature of the instrument, users needed several sessions of training before working independently, including sample preparation, set up and calibration, trouble shooting, and data analysis.  Currently over 30 individuals have been trained at this in- depth level including 6 faculty (2 female), 10 graduate students (6 female; 4 minority) and 16 undergraduate students (14 female; 2 minority).   Both faculty and students were actively using the instrument in their research projects and results were disseminated to the general public through publications, poster presentations at scientific conferences, and invited talks. Several graduate and undergraduate students included results obtained from this instrument in their Master?s thesis or Senior thesis projects.  

 

In addition to research projects, we presented hands-on workshop modules for undergraduate students as part of several University courses.  More than 100 students (graduate and undergraduate) participated in hands-on workshops as part of their immunology and biotechnology courses during the grant period.  Another 48 undergraduate students in our medical laboratory sciences major also got hands-on experience.  During COVID, access was limited to the facility and so we developed some virtual training exercises for the students. More than 50 students participated in the virtual trainings.  Finally, a few weeks after the grant period ended, another group of medical laboratory science students came for the hands-on workshop and we plan to continue these course workshops in the future. Many of these students were female and/or from underrepresented minority backgrounds.

 

Overall, the award has helped us expand our research capabilities on campus, increased participation in STEM activities by underrepresented minorities and women, improved teaching and learning through hands-on workshops across university departments, and helped develop the technical workforce as flow cytometry is a valuable skill for both clinical and basic research careers.
